title: MLB DFS Plays: Tuesday 9/10
text:
This article will outline the best daily fantasy MLB plays of the day at every position. We’ll take a comprehensive look across the DFS industry to uncover these core recommendations, factoring respective salaries into the analysis.

Please note, these player picks were organized early in the day. For MLB contests, always check lineups and weather closer to game time. Rain, wind, or unexpected managerial decisions could open up additional sources of value. Be sure to keep an eye on the MLB Headlines and Injuries desk.

Editor’s Note: Stay ahead of the competition from wire to wire with rankings, customizable projections, trade evaluator, exclusive columns and more in our Season Pass. And start using optimized lineups with our DFS Toolkit!

Scroll to continue with content Ad

We will be looking at the 14-game main slate starting at 7:05 ET.

PITCHER

Max Fried - Atlanta (at Philadelphia)

Fried continues to enjoy a breakout season after twirling back-to-back gems over the past 10 days. He combined to allow just three earned runs (five hits) with 20 strikeouts through 13 innings against the White Sox and Nationals. Tonight’s matchup at Philadelphia sounds more intimidating than it actually is, as the Phillies rank 19th in wRC+ this season with an above-average strikeout rate (23%) to boot. Fried checks in as a -165 road favorite, and I feel comfortable backing him through all DFS formats.

Also Consider: Walker Buehler, Jose Quintana

CATCHER / FIRST BASE

Eric Thames - Milwaukee (at Miami)

Story continues

The park factor isn’t great, but I’m still looking towards Thames in DFS this evening. His salary is relaxed, and the matchup is outstanding while facing Miami RHP Elieser Hernandez’s .392 wOBA split to left-handed bats. Thames has recorded six hits with two homers over his last five starts, and I’m expecting him to come through tonight.

Also Consider: Carlos Santana, Brandon Belt, David Freese

SECOND BASE

Kolten Wong - St. Louis (at Colorado)

The Cardinals check in with the highest run-scoring projection of the night, as they’ll travel to the hitting utopia of Coors Field. The matchup is certainly favorable as well, given that RHP Chi Chi Gonzalez (7.29 ERA) will take the bump for Colorado. Gonzalez holds an inflated .417 wOBA split to left-handed bats, meaning Kolten Wong is ripe for the picking in DFS.

Also Consider: Ozzie Albies, Cory Spangenberg

THIRD BASE

Matt Carpenter - St. Louis (at Colorado)

As mentioned in the previous write-up, Colorado RHP Gonzalez has been terrible against left-handed bats. Carpenter had a brutal cold-streak through most of August, but he’s seemingly finding his groove while going 5-7 with two doubles, two runs, and two RBIs over his last three games. Needless to say, this is an excellent spot for a breakout performance.

Also consider: Justin Turner, Yoan Moncada

SHORTSTOP

Paul DeJong - St. Louis (at Colorado)

DeJong isn’t left-handed, so he won’t have an opportunity to cash in on that aforementioned vulnerability of Colorado RHP Gonzalez. However, the Cardinals’ shortstop has been sizzling with five hits, two homers, four runs, and five RBIs over his past five games. The move to hitter-friendly Coors Field enhances that upside.

Also Consider: Trevor Story, Dansby Swanson

OUTFIELD

Franmil Reyes - Cleveland (at LA Angels)

Reyes carries a mid-range salary on most DFS sites, and I’m really excited about his floor/ceiling combination tonight. The matchup creates room for optimism, as LAA LHP Jose Suarez has struggled at the major league level by holding a 6.45 ERA with 84 hits allowed through 68.1 innings. Reyes has been warming up over the past week, and he should enjoy the platoon advantage in this confident draw.

Chris Taylor - LA Dodgers (at Baltimore)

As mentioned earlier, the Cardinals represent the highest run-scoring projection of the night. The Dodgers are right behind them while facing a terrible Orioles’ pitching staff in Baltimore. In other words, you’ll want some exposure to the mighty LAD lineup. A.J. Pollock and Justin Turner are prime lifts against Baltimore LHP Ty Blach, but Taylor represents an affordable option with capable upside. The Dodgers’ utility man has collected seven hits with two homers and five runs over his past five starts.

Also consider: Christian Yelich, Aristides Aquino, A.J. Pollock, Dexter Fowler, Tommy Edman, Yasiel Puig, Josh Reddick, Trent Grisham
